Environmental Burden: Ashburn, VA shows a very high cumulative footprint due to clustering of ~48 data centers. Key pressures include: (1) rapid electricity load growth requiring grid upgrades and potentially higher rates; (2) cooling energy and, where evaporative systems are used, sizable freshwater consumption and heat rejection; (3) backup‑generator NOx/PM during testing or grid events; (4) noise from chillers and rooftop equipment; (5) conversion of industrial/greenfield parcels into large warehouse campuses increasing impervious surface and traffic.
Policy Response: Recommended actions for Ashburn, VA: update zoning to explicitly define data‑center use; apply overlay districts with buffers, height/noise standards and generator‑testing limits; require annual public reporting of electricity and water use; set performance standards (PUE/WUE targets), closed‑loop or non‑potable cooling where feasible; tie tax abatements to Community Benefit Agreements (CBAs) for workforce training, stormwater/road improvements and public Wi‑Fi; coordinate interconnection and capacity planning with utilities; encourage on‑site/near‑site renewable procurement or PPAs; deploy construction traffic management and heat‑island mitigation (trees, cool roofs).
Community Voice: Residents and local groups in Ashburn, VA commonly raise concerns about 24/7 noise, diesel generator testing, water draw in hot months, and transparency of tax deals. Community priorities include earlier notice and public hearings, third‑party environmental reviews, monitoring sensors for noise/air, and negotiated CBAs that fund local education, job training, and green space in buffer zones.
